messageBody:
Yagiz Erkan wrote:

> Hi,
>
> Somebody mentioned jWebUnit yesterday. I had a look at it and it looks
> very
> easy to use. However it looks more like a smoke testing framework
> rather than a
> unit testing framework. We're thinking about using it with scenario based
> tests. I am missing something? If you guys write unit test with jWebUnit,
> what's your "unit"? A request? Two requests? A scenario?

For a typical web application, there are some concerns: each test (a
void testXXX() method) gets its own session. So to test a particular
webpage in your application, you'll need some navigation. This will
constantly test the sanity of the steps in your application (the best
thing is to click() on a link, and then assert that the title of the
received page equals your expectation). This way you *always* know
you're on the right page.

When you reach the page you want to test, you typically try to test all
fields, all validations, etc. So there will be a SearchCustomerPageTest,
AddCustomerPageTest, EditCustomerPageTest. One 'unit' test could be to
try to add a customer twice.

I also try to do complete use case scenarios, just to be sure those also
work. Here I usually violate the 'each test must run independently'
rule. So testAddCustomerScenario() will add one customer,
testFindCustomerScenario() will assert that that customer could be found
(in a new session). These constitute the integration tests.

void testScenario() {
searchForCustomerNotFound("Martijn", "Dashorst");
addNewCustomer("Martijn", "Dashorst", "Street 10", "12345", "City",
"Country");
assertTitleEquals("Customer data");
assertTextPresent("Customer added");
gotoSearchPetPage();
searchForCat("Siamese");

addCatToCar();
checkCarContents,
checkOut,
etc.
}

Hope this helps.

Martijn
